definitions: believing that people and situations can be perfect rather than accepting reality
motivated by high principles and noble goals rather than practical concerns
examples: Her idealistic vision of society ignored harsh economic realities
Young graduates often enter careers with idealistic expectations
The idealistic principles of democracy guide many political movements
His idealistic approach to business focused on ethics over profits

definitions: portrayed or imagined as better than reality, often with flaws removed
regarded with excessive admiration that ignores actual imperfections
examples: The movie presented an idealized version of small-town life
Her idealized memories of childhood overlooked difficult times
He had an idealized view of his absent father
The idealized romance in novels rarely matches real relationships

definitions: possible to recognize or establish who or what someone or something is
able to be distinguished from others or determined through specific characteristics
examples: The suspect was easily identifiable by his distinctive tattoo
Each product has identifiable features that set it apart
The disease has several identifiable symptoms doctors look for
Her writing style is immediately identifiable to regular readers

definitions: recognized or discovered the identity of someone or something through examination
closely connected with or feeling sympathy for a particular group or idea
examples: Police identified the victim through dental records
Scientists identified several new species in the rainforest
She strongly identified with the immigrant community's struggles
Many voters identified with the candidate's working-class background

definitions: using language in a way that sounds natural to native speakers
containing expressions whose meaning differs from individual word meanings
examples: Her idiomatic English impressed the interview panel
Students struggle to write idiomatic expressions in foreign languages
The text is full of idiomatic phrases difficult to translate
Regional idiomatic expressions can confuse visitors from elsewhere

definitions: relating to habits or characteristics unique to a particular person
having unusual features that distinguish something from others of its type
examples: His idiosyncratic teaching methods confused some students
The artist developed an idiosyncratic style nobody could imitate
The software has several idiosyncratic features users must learn
Her idiosyncratic pronunciation revealed her mixed cultural background

definitions: very stupid or showing an extreme lack of intelligence or common sense
so foolish as to be offensive or cause frustration in others
examples: It was idiotic to drive in such dangerous weather
His idiotic comments ruined the serious discussion
The idiotic policy wasted millions of taxpayer dollars
She made an idiotic mistake by trusting him again

definitions: not engaged in work or activity; doing nothing productive
having no particular purpose or basis; serving no useful function
lacking truth or foundation; based on speculation rather than fact
examples: The machines sat idle during the factory strike
Workers remained idle while waiting for supplies to arrive
His idle threats never resulted in any action
She spent idle hours browsing social media
Their idle gossip spread false rumors through town
These idle speculations won't solve our real problems

definitions: loved or admired very much, often to an unreasonable degree
regarded as perfect or worthy of worship without acknowledging flaws
examples: Teenagers idolized the famous pop star
He idolized his older brother throughout childhood
The idolized athlete's scandal shocked devoted fans
She idolized her mentor until discovering his dishonesty

definitions: extremely pleasant, beautiful, and peaceful, seeming perfect like paradise
characterized by simple perfection and contentment, often unrealistically so
examples: They spent an idyllic vacation on the tropical island
The cottage offered an idyllic retreat from city stress
Her idyllic childhood on the farm shaped her values
The couple lived an idyllic life until tragedy struck

definitions: formed through solidification of molten rock material from Earth's interior
of or relating to fire or the geological processes involving extreme heat
examples: Granite is an igneous rock formed deep underground
The island's igneous formations resulted from ancient volcanic activity
Igneous processes created the dramatic cliff formations
Students examined igneous rock samples under microscopes

definitions: caught fire or caused something to start burning through heat or spark
triggered intense feelings, reactions, or situations to suddenly begin or intensify
examples: The match ignited the pile of dry leaves
Sparks from the welding torch ignited nearby materials
Her speech ignited passion in the crowd
The scandal ignited fierce debate across social media

definitions: intentionally refused to take notice of or acknowledge someone or something
failed to consider or address something that should receive attention
examples: She ignored his repeated attempts to apologize
The manager ignored employee complaints about safety
They ignored warning signs of structural damage
The report ignored crucial data that contradicted conclusions

definitions: suffering from disease or poor health; not feeling well physically
causing harm or unfavorable results; characterized by hostility or malice
inadequate, unsatisfactory, or not meeting acceptable standards
examples: She felt too ill to attend the meeting
The ill patient required immediate medical attention
His ill intentions became clear over time
They bore ill will toward their former partner
The ill effects of pollution damage the environment
It was an ill choice to trust him

definitions: not clear enough to be read due to poor handwriting or print quality
so poorly expressed or presented that meaning cannot be determined
examples: The doctor's illegible handwriting confused the pharmacist
Rain made the old sign completely illegible
His illegible notes were useless for studying
The faded document became illegible after years

definitions: not allowed by law or rules; lacking legal or official approval
born to parents who were not married to each other at time of birth
examples: The court ruled the election results illegitimate
Their illegitimate business practices led to prosecution
Historical novels often feature illegitimate heirs seeking recognition
The term illegitimate child is now considered outdated

definitions: not allowed by law, rules, or social customs; illegal or improper
kept secret because morally wrong or against accepted standards
examples: Police discovered an illicit drug manufacturing operation
The company engaged in illicit trade practices
Their illicit affair destroyed both marriages
He made money through illicit gambling activities

definitions: unable to read or write due to lack of education or learning
having little or no knowledge in a particular subject or area
examples: Many illiterate adults hide their inability to read
The program helps illiterate immigrants learn basic skills
He was financially illiterate and made poor investments
Being computer illiterate limits job opportunities today

definitions: not following rules of logic or clear reasoning; contradicting rational thought
failing to make sense or show good judgment in thinking or planning
examples: His illogical argument contained several contradictions
The illogical plot made the movie hard to follow
It seems illogical to close profitable stores
Her illogical fear of birds started in childhood

definitions: brightened with light to make visible or prominent
decorated with gold, silver, and colored designs, especially in manuscripts
having achieved spiritual or intellectual insight and understanding
examples: Street lamps illuminated the dark pathway
The illuminated sign attracted customers at night
Medieval monks created beautifully illuminated manuscripts
The illuminated letters began each chapter
His illuminated mind grasped complex philosophical concepts
She felt illuminated after years of meditation

definitions: helping to clarify or explain something by providing insight or information
producing light or brightness that makes things visible
examples: Her illuminating comments clarified the complex issue
The documentary provided illuminating insights into poverty
The illuminating torch revealed hidden cave paintings
Scientists use illuminating dyes to track cell movement

definitions: based on false ideas or beliefs; not real despite appearing to be
likely to deceive or mislead by creating false impressions
examples: His illusory sense of security vanished during crisis
The desert creates illusory images through heat mirages
Their illusory profits hid massive debts underneath
The illusory nature of fame became clear

definitions: helping to explain or make something clear by providing examples
using pictures, diagrams, or decorations to clarify or enhance text
examples: The case study was illustrative of broader trends
She used illustrative examples to explain complex concepts
The illustrative diagrams helped students understand anatomy
His illustrative sketches brought the story alive

definitions: well known and respected for past achievements or high position
notably outstanding and bringing honor through remarkable accomplishments
examples: The university boasts many illustrious alumni
Her illustrious career spanned five decades
He comes from an illustrious family of scientists
The illustrious history of the regiment inspired recruits

definitions: capable of being imagined or conceived in the mind
possible to think of or consider as potentially existing or happening
examples: They tried every imaginable solution to the problem
The storm caused the worst imaginable damage
Life on Mars is now imaginable with new technology
She couldn't think of any imaginable excuse

definitions: existing only in the mind or imagination, not in reality
created by imagination rather than based on facts or actual events
examples: Children often have imaginary friends
The novel takes place in an imaginary kingdom
His imaginary illnesses worried his family
They fought against imaginary enemies

definitions: having or showing creativity and original ideas, especially in art
able to think of new and interesting ideas or possibilities
examples: The imaginative design won international awards
Her imaginative stories captivated young readers
He found imaginative solutions to budget constraints
The chef created imaginative combinations of flavors

definitions: not evenly distributed or in correct proportions; lacking equilibrium
showing signs of mental or emotional instability
examples: The imbalanced budget favored military spending
An imbalanced diet can cause health problems
His imbalanced behavior concerned his colleagues
The medication helps imbalanced brain chemistry

definitions: filled or permeated with a particular quality, feeling, or influence
inspired or influenced deeply with ideas, principles, or emotions
examples: The speech was imbued with hope and optimism
Her paintings are imbued with vibrant energy
He was imbued with his grandfather's values
The culture is imbued with ancient traditions

definitions: made to look like something else, usually something more expensive
not genuine but made to appear like the real thing
examples: She wore imitation pearls to the party
The imitation leather looked surprisingly realistic
They served imitation crab made from fish
Imitation vanilla extract costs less than real

definitions: copying or following a model or example rather than being original
tending to copy the behavior, style, or ideas of others
examples: Young children's imitative behavior helps them learn
His imitative art style lacked personal vision
The imitative design borrowed heavily from competitors
Monkeys show highly imitative learning abilities

definitions: completely clean and tidy with no marks or messiness
perfect and without any mistakes, faults, or bad qualities
examples: She kept an immaculate house despite having children
His immaculate white suit impressed the interviewer
The goalkeeper maintained an immaculate record all season
Her immaculate reputation helped win the election

definitions: existing or operating within; inherent as a permanent attribute
present throughout the universe or within the mind as a guiding force
examples: They believed divine power was immanent in nature
The immanent qualities of the material determine strength
His philosophy explored immanent consciousness in all beings
Change is immanent in all living systems

definitions: not relevant or significant to the matter being considered
having no physical existence; spiritual rather than physical in nature
examples: The color is immaterial as long as it works
These minor details are immaterial to our decision
They discussed immaterial concepts like souls and spirits
The immaterial world fascinated the philosopher

definitions: not fully grown or developed physically, mentally, or emotionally
showing behavior more appropriate to someone much younger; lacking wisdom
examples: The immature fruit tasted bitter and hard
Immature trees need protection from strong winds
His immature response to criticism upset everyone
Their immature jokes disrupted the serious meeting

definitions: too large, extensive, or extreme to measure or calculate accurately
so great in size or degree that it cannot be expressed in numbers
examples: The universe contains immeasurable distances between galaxies
Her contribution brought immeasurable value to research
The tragedy caused immeasurable suffering to families
His kindness had immeasurable impact on students

definitions: extending back beyond memory, record, or knowledge; extremely ancient
so long established that its origin cannot be remembered or discovered
examples: The tribe followed customs from time immemorial
These hills have stood since time immemorial
The immemorial traditions bind the community together
Rights established by immemorial usage remain valid

definitions: extremely large in size, degree, or amount; too big to measure
unusually great in degree or intensity; having remarkable impact
examples: The immense building dominated the city skyline
Whales travel immense distances during migration
She felt immense relief when he survived
The project required immense dedication and effort

definitions: about to happen very soon, especially within moments or days
hanging threateningly over one's head; ready to befall or overtake
examples: The weather service warned of imminent tornadoes
Her imminent arrival made everyone prepare quickly
The country faced imminent economic collapse
Signs pointed to imminent danger ahead

definitions: not able to move or be moved from current position
remaining in one place without moving; stationary or motionless
examples: The accident left him immobile for months
Fear made her completely immobile
The immobile statue stood for centuries
Traffic was immobile during rush hour

definitions: not conforming to accepted standards of morality or ethical behavior
morally wrong according to social or religious principles of right conduct
examples: Many consider lying immoral in any circumstance
The company's immoral practices led to boycotts
He struggled with immoral thoughts and desires
Society deemed their relationship immoral

definitions: living forever; never dying or decaying through natural processes
deserving to be remembered forever due to outstanding achievements
examples: Ancient myths featured immortal gods and goddesses
Scientists search for ways to make cells immortal
Shakespeare's immortal words inspire readers today
Her immortal performance defined the role

definitions: impossible to move from place due to size, weight, or fixation
not able to be changed or persuaded; firmly fixed in purpose
examples: The immovable boulder blocked the mountain path
Ancient builders created seemingly immovable structures
She remained immovable in her decision to quit
His immovable stance frustrated negotiators

definitions: relating to the branch of medicine studying immunity and immune responses
of or concerning the body's system for protecting against disease
examples: The patient showed strong immunological response to treatment
Immunological research led to new vaccine development
She studies immunological disorders affecting children
The immunological tests revealed multiple allergies

definitions: unchanging over time or unable to be changed by any means
fundamental and permanent in nature; not subject to variation
examples: They believed in immutable laws of physics
Death remains an immutable fact of life
His immutable principles guided every decision
The immutable data cannot be altered once written

definitions: strongly affected or influenced by something, usually negatively
pressed or wedged firmly together so movement is prevented
examples: The storm impacted coastal communities severely
Budget cuts impacted educational programs significantly
The impacted wisdom tooth required surgical removal
Impacted soil prevents proper water drainage

definitions: weakened or damaged, especially relating to a faculty or function
having a disability or reduced function in a particular area
examples: His impaired vision required strong prescription glasses
Alcohol consumption resulted in impaired judgment
The accident left her with impaired mobility
Students with impaired hearing use sign language

definitions: treating all rivals or disputants equally without favoritism
not supporting one side over another; fair and unbiased
examples: The judge remained impartial throughout the trial
Journalists should provide impartial news coverage
An impartial mediator helped resolve the dispute
The committee sought impartial expert opinions

definitions: impossible to travel along or through due to obstacles or conditions
blocked or obstructed so that passage is not possible
examples: Heavy snow made mountain roads impassable
The swollen river was impassable without boats
Fallen trees created impassable forest trails
The impassable terrain forced explorers to retreat

definitions: filled with or showing great emotion or passion about something
expressing strong feelings with intensity and fervor
examples: She delivered an impassioned speech about justice
His impassioned plea moved the jury to tears
The protesters made impassioned demands for change
Their impassioned love letters revealed deep feelings
